newsitem.title: UK: BA says cargo shipments being maintained.
newsitem.headline: BA says cargo shipments being maintained.

text.p: British Airways Plc cargo shipments on operational flights are being maintained at around the levels seen yesterday, a BA World Cargo spokesman said.
Flights have been hit by the 72-hour strike of BA cabin crew which started earlier on Wednesday.
To the Far East flights are close to capacity for freight while the overall cargo load factor on long-haul flights is more than 70 percent, the spokesman added.

The latter figure indicates cargo capacity is still available on some operational flights and generally cargo customers have been understanding about the impact of the strike todate on freight shipments, he added.
Today, Thursday, saw some extra long-haul routes back into service including two flights from London to San Francisco and one via New Delhi to Dhaka in Bangladesh, the spokesman said.
BA Cargo handles a weekly average of 9,000 tonnes of air freight at Heathrow and 4,000 tonnes at Gatwick, he added.
On July 7, BA said its scheduled freighter flights will operate normally during the strike and that they would not seek to obtain extra cargo space from other airlines.

The airline has said it expects it will take one to three days to return fully to normal cargo operations once the strike ends on July 12. - Reuters Air Cargo Service Tel+ 44 171 542 7706 Fax +5017 - www.racs.com
